enum.name: MAV_AUTOPILOT
enum.description: Micro air vehicle / autopilot classes. This identifies the individual model.

entry.name: MAV_AUTOPILOT_GENERIC
entry.description: Generic autopilot, full support for everything

entry.name: MAV_AUTOPILOT_GENERIC_WAYPOINTS_ONLY
entry.description: Generic autopilot only supporting simple waypoints

entry.name: MAV_AUTOPILOT_GENERIC_WAYPOINTS_AND_SIMPLE_NAVIGATION_ONLY
entry.description: Generic autopilot supporting waypoints and other simple navigation commands

entry.name: MAV_AUTOPILOT_GENERIC_MISSION_FULL
entry.description: Generic autopilot supporting the full mission command set

entry.name: MAV_AUTOPILOT_INVALID
entry.description: No valid autopilot, e.g. a GCS or other MAVLink component

enum.name: MAV_TYPE
enum.description: MAVLINK system type. All components in a system should report this type in their HEARTBEAT.

entry.name: MAV_TYPE_GCS
entry.description: Operator control unit / ground control station

entry.name: MAV_TYPE_VTOL_DUOROTOR
entry.description: Two-rotor VTOL using control surfaces in vertical operation in addition. Tailsitter.

entry.name: MAV_TYPE_VTOL_QUADROTOR
entry.description: Quad-rotor VTOL using a V-shaped quad config in vertical operation. Tailsitter.

enum.name: MAV_MODE_FLAG
enum.description: These flags encode the MAV mode.

entry.name: MAV_MODE_FLAG_SAFETY_ARMED
entry.description: 0b10000000 MAV safety set to armed. Motors are enabled / running / can start. Ready to fly. Additional note: this flag is to be ignore when sent in the command MAV_CMD_DO_SET_MODE and MAV_CMD_COMPONENT_ARM_DISARM shall be used instead. The flag can still be used to report the armed state.

entry.name: MAV_MODE_FLAG_HIL_ENABLED
entry.description: 0b00100000 hardware in the loop simulation. All motors / actuators are blocked, but internal software is full operational.

entry.name: MAV_MODE_FLAG_STABILIZE_ENABLED
entry.description: 0b00010000 system stabilizes electronically its attitude (and optionally position). It needs however further control inputs to move around.

entry.name: MAV_MODE_FLAG_GUIDED_ENABLED
entry.description: 0b00001000 guided mode enabled, system flies waypoints / mission items.

entry.name: MAV_MODE_FLAG_AUTO_ENABLED
entry.description: 0b00000100 autonomous mode enabled, system finds its own goal positions. Guided flag can be set or not, depends on the actual implementation.

entry.name: MAV_MODE_FLAG_TEST_ENABLED
entry.description: 0b00000010 system has a test mode enabled. This flag is intended for temporary system tests and should not be used for stable implementations.

enum.name: MAV_MODE_FLAG_DECODE_POSITION
enum.description: These values encode the bit positions of the decode position. These values can be used to read the value of a flag bit by combining the base_mode variable with AND with the flag position value. The result will be either 0 or 1, depending on if the flag is set or not.

entry.name: MAV_STATE_CALIBRATING
entry.description: System is calibrating and not flight-ready.

entry.name: MAV_STATE_STANDBY
entry.description: System is grounded and on standby. It can be launched any time.

entry.name: MAV_STATE_ACTIVE
entry.description: System is active and might be already airborne. Motors are engaged.

entry.name: MAV_STATE_CRITICAL
entry.description: System is in a non-normal flight mode. It can however still navigate.

entry.name: MAV_STATE_EMERGENCY
entry.description: System is in a non-normal flight mode. It lost control over parts or over the whole airframe. It is in mayday and going down.

entry.name: MAV_STATE_POWEROFF
entry.description: System just initialized its power-down sequence, will shut down now.

enum.name: MAV_COMPONENT
enum.description: Component ids (values) for the different types and instances of onboard hardware/software that might make up a MAVLink system (autopilot, cameras, servos, GPS systems, avoidance systems etc.). Components must use the appropriate ID in their source address when sending messages. Components can also use IDs to determine if they are the intended recipient of an incoming message. The MAV_COMP_ID_ALL value is used to indicate messages that must be processed by all components. When creating new entries, components that can have multiple instances (e.g. cameras, servos etc.) should be allocated sequential values. An appropriate number of values should be left free after these components to allow the number of instances to be expanded.

entry.name: MAV_COMP_ID_ALL
entry.description: Used to broadcast messages to all components of the receiving system. Components should attempt to process messages with this component ID and forward to components on any other interfaces.

entry.name: MAV_COMP_ID_AUTOPILOT1
entry.description: System flight controller component ("autopilot"). Only one autopilot is expected in a particular system.

entry.name: MAV_COMP_ID_OSD
entry.description: On Screen Display (OSD) devices for video links.

entry.name: MAV_COMP_ID_PERIPHERAL
entry.description: Generic autopilot peripheral component ID. Meant for devices that do not implement the parameter microservice.

entry.name: MAV_COMP_ID_MISSIONPLANNER
entry.description: Component that can generate/supply a mission flight plan (e.g. GCS or developer API).

entry.name: MAV_COMP_ID_PATHPLANNER
entry.description: Component that finds an optimal path between points based on a certain constraint (e.g. minimum snap, shortest path, cost, etc.).

entry.name: MAV_COMP_ID_OBSTACLE_AVOIDANCE
entry.description: Component that plans a collision free path between two points.

entry.name: MAV_COMP_ID_VISUAL_INERTIAL_ODOMETRY
entry.description: Component that provides position estimates using VIO techniques.

entry.name: MAV_COMP_ID_UDP_BRIDGE
entry.description: Component to bridge MAVLink to UDP (i.e. from a UART).

entry.name: MAV_COMP_ID_UART_BRIDGE
entry.description: Component to bridge to UART (i.e. from UDP).

entry.name: MAV_COMP_ID_SYSTEM_CONTROL
entry.deprecated: System control does not require a separate component ID.
entry.description: Component for handling system messages (e.g. to ARM, takeoff, etc.).

enum.name: MAV_CMD
enum.description: Commands to be executed by the MAV. They can be executed on user request, or as part of a mission script. If the action is used in a mission, the parameter mapping to the waypoint/mission message is as follows: Param 1, Param 2, Param 3, Param 4, X: Param 5, Y:Param 6, Z:Param 7. This command list is similar what ARINC 424 is for commercial aircraft: A data format how to interpret waypoint/mission data. See https://mavlink.io/en/guide/xml_schema.html#MAV_CMD for information about the structure of the MAV_CMD entries

entry.name: MAV_CMD_REQUEST_PROTOCOL_VERSION
entry.param: 1: Request supported protocol versions by all nodes on the network

message.name: HEARTBEAT
message.description: The heartbeat message shows that a system or component is present and responding. The type and autopilot fields (along with the message component id), allow the receiving system to treat further messages from this system appropriately (e.g. by laying out the user interface based on the autopilot). This microservice is documented at https://mavlink.io/en/services/heartbeat.html
message.field: Type of the system (quadrotor, helicopter, etc.). Components use the same type as their associated system.
A bitfield for use for autopilot-specific flags
MAVLink version, not writable by user, gets added by protocol because of magic data type: uint8_t_mavlink_version

message.name: PROTOCOL_VERSION
message.description: Version and capability of protocol version. This message is the response to REQUEST_PROTOCOL_VERSION and is used as part of the handshaking to establish which MAVLink version should be used on the network. Every node should respond to REQUEST_PROTOCOL_VERSION to enable the handshaking. Library implementers should consider adding this into the default decoding state machine to allow the protocol core to respond directly.
message.field: Currently active MAVLink version number * 100: v1.0 is 100, v2.0 is 200, etc.
Maximum MAVLink version supported (set to the same value as version by default)
The first 8 bytes (not characters printed in hex!) of the git hash.
The first 8 bytes (not characters printed in hex!) of the git hash.
